metadata.title: Novel 3D flower-like micro/nano-structure FeS/N-doped-C composites as advanced cathodes with high lithium storage performances

sections.heading: Available online 28 May 2019
sections.text:
0378-7753/© 2019 Elsevier B.V. All rights reserved.
Short communication
Novel 3D flower-like micro/nano-structure FeS/N-doped-C composites as advanced cathodes with high lithium storage performances
Jian Xie a,*,1, Javier Carrasco b,1, Rongrong Li c,d,e,1, Hangjia Shen c,d, Qiong Chen a, Minghui Yang c,d,**
a School of Chemistry and Environmental Engineering, Hanshan Normal University, Chaozhou, 521041, China b CIC EnergiGUNE, Albert Einstein 48, E-01510, Mineano, Spain c Solid State Functional Materials Research Laboratory, Ningbo Institute of Materials Technology and Engineering, Chinese Academy of Sciences, Ningbo, 315201, China d Center of Materials Science and Optoelectronics Engineering, University of Chinese Academy of Sciences, Beijing, 100049, China e University of Chinese Academy of Sciences, Beijing, 100049, China
H I G H L I G H T S G R A P H I C A L A B S T R A C T
� A creative synthesis method of FeS/Ndoped-C composites is proposed. � FeS/N-doped-C composites own unique
3D flower-like micro/nano-structures. � FeS/N-doped-C composites are evalu-
ated as cathodes for the first time. � FeS/N-doped-C electrodes exhibit
extraordinary cycling stability and rate capability. � Using DFT calculations, molecular-level
insight into the role of N-doping is given.
A R T I C L E I N F O

sections.heading: Keywords:
sections.text:
Micro/nano-structures Iron sulfides N-doped carbon composites Lithium storage Density functional theory calculations
A B S T R A C T
Due to their merits of high capacity, abundant resources and environmental benignity, Fe monosulfides are considered as attractive electrode materials for Li-ion batteries. However, inferior cyclability and rate performances resulted from inherent low conductivity limit their applications. Herein, we present novel 3D flower-like micro/nano-structure FeS/N-doped-C composites which are directly synthesized from low-cost organosulfur compounds through facile precipitation and subsequent calcination and for the first time applied as cathodes for lithium storage. The FeS nanoparticles are coated by highly conductive N-doped-C shells. Such a confinement of coating microstructures, especially outer N-doped-C, is highly beneficial for the conversion reactions (FeSþ2Liþþ2e ↔Fe þ Li2S), and could strengthen conductivity and simultaneously better protect FeS from electrolyte corrosions, ensuring stable conductive frameworks. Also, such N-doped-C anchor FeS, Fe, and Li2S effectively, as confirmed by density functional theory calculations. Thus, the FeS/N-doped-C cathodes exhibit remarkable cycling stability (621 mAh g 1 at 200th cycle at 1C, with a decay of 0.07%/cycle), and high rate performances (600 mAh g 1 even at 10C), delivering higher energy density than commercial LiCoO2 cathodes. This work discloses a novel and paramount route to exploit transition metal sulfides for lithium storage and helps us further understand the key role of N-doping in electrochemical energy storage.
* Corresponding author. School of Chemistry and Environmental Engineering, Hanshan Normal University, Chaozhou, 521041, China. ** Corresponding author. Solid State Functional Materials Research Laboratory, Ningbo Institute of Materials Technology and Engineering, Chinese Academy of
Sciences, Ningbo, 315201, China. E-mail addresses: xiejian@hstc.edu.cn (J. Xie), myang@nimte.ac.cn (M. Yang).
1 These authors contributed equally to this work.
Contents lists available at ScienceDirect
Journal of Power Sources
journal homepage: www.elsevier.com/locate/jpowsour
https://doi.org/10.1016/j.jpowsour.2019.05.041 Received 18 February 2019; Received in revised form 16 April 2019; Accepted 11 May 2019
Journal of Power Sources 431 (2019) 226–231

sections.heading: 1. Introduction
sections.text:
Most commercial Li-ion batteries (LIBs) are still based on graphite anodes and insertion-type LiMO2 (M ¼ transition metal) cathodes to date. Yet these systems cannot meet increasing requirements for high energy density of large grid energy storage and electric vehicles (EVs). [1–3] In order to increase the energy density, tremendous research efforts have been carried out in decades. [4] However, while various potential anode materials are available nowadays, this is not the case for cathodes. By involving multiple electrons per metal ion, transition metal sulfides based on conversion reactions are projected as promising substitutions to traditional intercalation-type oxide cathode materials. Among them, naturally abundant and environmentally friendly iron monosulfides (FeS) are of particular interest, owning to their reasonably good Li storage capability (compared with FeS2) and high theoretical capacity of ~609 mAh g 1 based on the full lithiation to Li2S (FeSþ2Liþþ2e →Fe þ Li2S), much higher than the state of the art popular Ni-rich LiNi0.8Co0.15Al0.05O2 cathodes (<200 mAh g 1). [5–7] Note that iron monosulfides are well investigated as both anode and cathode materials for LIBs, which regarded as cathodes in the early stage and recently developed into potential anodes tested in voltage ranges of 0–3 V (vs. Li/Liþ). [8–12]
Taking into account good safety and high capacity, FeS are still regarded as promising cathodes in spite of low operating potential, i.e., 1.5 V. [8] However, further applications are hindered by rapid capacity losses, resulting from low conductivity FeS, nonreactive α-Fe phase and highly resistive Li2S formed during conversion reactions (FeSþ2Liþþ2e ↔Fe þ Li2S). [13] Thus, modifying FeS as cathodes for Li storage is needed.
As comprehensive modifications, constructing nano and composite structures are efficient to design better cathodes for LIBs. For example, Zhang et al. [14] synthesized FeS nanosheets by PVA-assisted precipitation. When evaluated as cathodes in all-solid-state LIB (0.5–3 V), these FeS delivered good rate properties. And Tran et al. [15] prepared carbon precursor coated FeS microcrystals via one-pot solvothermal reactions, exhibiting excellent rate capability (1.0–2.3/2.6 V). Also, FeS nanodots in graphitic carbon nanowires were reported via electrospinning and hydrothermal methods [13], and tested as cathodes (1-3 V). Such composites showed high lithium storage performances. Reddy et al. [16] reported FeS/microporous carbon (MC) nanocomposites by reacting S-infused MC precursors with Fe (CO)5. But when tested as LIB cathodes in 1–3 V, the FeS/MC exhibited limited cycling performances. In addition, flexible FeS/C/carbon cloths were prepared and used as cathodes (1.0–2.6 V) for LIBs, showing good cycling stability. [17]
From a theoretical viewpoint, Craco et al. [18] undertook a study of FeS for LIBs and reported the untraditional phenomenon of orbital-selective metallic states in FeS at high electron doping. Recently, N-doping has been employed to create active sites, modify surface chemistry and local electronic properties of carbon materials. Hence, N-doped-C/FeS (FeS/NDC) composites [19–21] were subsequently reported, but not used as the cathodes for lithium storage. Also, exploiting novel and facile synthesis methods is still challenging. Moreover, modified mechanisms of N-doping need to be further investigated.
Herein, unlike conventional methods, we direct synthesize micro/ nano-structure FeS/NDC composites from cheap organosulfur compounds through facile precipitation and subsequent calcination, without toxic precursors, surfactants and harmful byproducts. Importantly, this is the first report on the employment of FeS/N-doped-C composites as active cathode materials for lithium storage. Such composites present 2D nanosheets, assembling into 3D flower-like ensembles. The individual FeS is coated by highly conductive NDC against electrolyte corrosions. Owning to unique NDC coating structures, FeS/NDC cathodes exhibit remarkable cycling stability and high rate performances. Moreover, we assess the adsorption energies of FeS, Fe, and Li2S on NDC by density functional theory (DFT) calculations. Compared with plain carbon, NDC anchors FeS, Fe and Li2S more effectively, which provides
further evidence for the outstanding lithium storage performances. This work discloses a novel and paramount route to exploit transition metal sulfides for lithium storage, and helps us deep understand the key role of N-doping in electrochemical energy storage.

sections.heading: 2. Experimental
sections.text:
The primary synthetic approach was to synthesize molecular precursor by mixing sodium DDTC, i.e., NaS2CN(C2H5)2, 6.3924 g, and FeCl2 (1.7973 g) in deionized (DI) water (100 mL). The iron (II) DDTC precursor formed instantly and precipitated as black powder. After stirring and black depositing for 1 h, the precipitates were separated, washed with DI water and ethanol. The dried iron (II) DDTC was calcinated at 700 �C for 2 h in Ar. Following this, the product was further heated at 400 �C for 1 h in NH3. After naturally cooling to room temperature, FeS/NDC composites were obtained.
The obtained FeS/NDC composites were characterized by X-ray diffraction (XRD, D/max-RB, Rigaku), scanning electron microscopy (SEM, JSM-7800F), transmission electron microscopy (TEM, Tecnai G2F30 S-Twin), thermogravimetric analysis (TGA, Perkin Elmer), and the X-ray photoelectron spectrometer (XPS, ESCALAB250).
The electrochemical performances were tested in CR2032 half-cells. Working electrodes consisted of FeS/NDC, super P, and PVDF in an 8: 1: 1 wt. ratio. Li foils were employed as reference and counter electrodes. The electrolyte was 1 M LiPF6 dissolved in EC, EMC and DMC. Galvanostatic discharge/charge measurements were conducted in the voltage window of 1–3 V. The mass loading of FeS for the electrodes was typically 1.0 mg cm 2. Note that all the capacity values presented in this work were based on the mass of FeS, which was determined by the TGA. CV and EIS testing were performed on a CHI 660E electrochemical workstation.
Spin-polarized DFT calculations were performed using supercell approach and Vienna ab initio simulation package (VASP, version 5.4.1). [22] We used semilocal Perdew-Burke-Ernzerhof (PBE) functional in combination with Grimme’s dispersion-corrected approach D3 with Becke-Johnson damping function (D3BJ). [23–25] We treated explicitly H (1s), Li (1s, 2s), C (2s, 2p), N (2s, 2p), S (3s, 3p), and Fe (3s, 3p, 3d, 4s) electrons as valence states expanded in plane waves with a cut-off energy of 600 eV, whereas the remaining electrons were replaced by PBE-based projector-augmented wave potentials. [26] The gas-phase FeS, Fe, and Li2S were calculated at the Γ-point using a (15 � 15 � 15) Å3 simulation box, which ensured that repeated image interactions were negligible. Structures to compute molecular adsorption were carried out in a (4 � 4) graphene periodic stripe model separated in the perpendicular (lateral) direction by 15.6 Å (12.2 Å); the dangling bonds at graphene edges were passivated by H atoms and different NDC models were created by replacing C with N atoms (Figs. S5–7). For all the systems investigated, a range of different initial geometries and orientations were considered and the structures were relaxed using a conjugate-gradient algorithm with a residual force threshold of 30 meV/Å. Integrals over the Brillouin zone were performed on a regular (2 � 5 � 1) k-point mesh. The adsorption energies of FeS, Fe, and Li2S on different sites were computed as follows:
Eads ¼ Em@NDC ENDC Em
Where Em@NDC, ENDC, and Em are DFT total energies of the complete adsorption system, relaxed bare (N-doped) graphene stripe, and gasphase FeS, Fe, or Li2S, respectively (Table S2). According to this definition, negative values of Em@NDC indicate exothermic adsorption.

sections.heading: 3. Results and discussion
sections.text:
Scheme 1 shows the schematic synthesis route of FeS/NDC composites. When heated to ~300 �C, the Fe (II) diethyldithiocarbamate (DDTC) precipitates melt and C-S bonds are gradually broken, forming
J. Xie et al.
Journal of Power Sources 431 (2019) 226–231
short-chain organic molecules and small FeS crystal nuclei. [27] The FeS crystals grow then to form 2D nanosheets, assembling into 3D flower-like ensembles. [14] Finally, calcinating at high temperatures in Ar/NH3 makes outside adsorbed organic molecules on FeS nanosheets turn into NDC layers. And 3D flower-like FeS/NDC composites are obtained.
The XRD pattern of our FeS/NDC composites (Fig. 1A) matches up well with that of troilite, with main reflections appearing at ~30�, 34�, 43�, 53�, and 71� indexed, respectively, to the (1 1 0), (1 1 2), (1 1 4), (3 0 0), and (2 2 4) planes of FeS (JCPDS No. 00-037-0477). [12,28] Other characteristic reflections of possible impurities are not detected, indicating good crystallinity. The broad and extremely weak dispersion reflections located in 20–30� suggest the presence of NDC. Based on TGA results (Fig. S1), carbon content of FeS/NDC composites is calculated to be ~17.5 wt.%. Note that the weight increase in 200–300 �C can be attributed to the oxidation of ferrous, while weight losses in 300–400 �C and 400-500 �C correspond to carbon and sulfur, respectively (Fig. S1). Fig. 1B and C show SEM images of FeS/NDC composites, revealing a morphology of 3D flower-like shapes assembled with 2D nanosheets. Corresponding EDS results for the SEM image (Fig. 1C) are shown in Table S1. The carbon content is 16 wt.%, in good agreement with TGA results. While the content of Fe and S is ~39 and 21 wt.%, respectively, corresponding to an almost 1:1 atomic ratio, i.e., FeS, which is consistent with ferrous sulfur observed with XRD. Typical TEM images displayed in
Fig. 1D and E further confirm the morphology of 2D nanosheet assembling 3D flower-like shapes. At higher resolutions (Fig. 1F), core-shell microstructures of FeS/NDC composites are shown. The outer NDC shell can be clearly seen, with ~2 nm in thickness, whereas the inner FeS core is obviously crystalline, with an interplanar spacing of ~2.98 Å (inset image of Fig. 1F) that corresponds to the (1 1 0) plane of FeS. High-angle annular dark-field scanning TEM (HAADF-STEM) and energy-dispersive X-ray (EDX) spectroscopy (Fig. 1G and H) further illustrate the distributions of Fe, S, C and N elements in FeS/NDC composites. Such a confinement of NDC coating structures, especially the outer NDC, is highly beneficial for conversion reactions and could strengthen conductivity and simultaneously better protect FeS from electrolyte corrosions, resulting in much stable conductive structures.
To further elucidate surface chemical environment of FeS/NDC composites, we performed XPS characterizations. A wide-range survey spectrum confirms the existence of Fe, S, C, N, and O elements (Fig. S2). The deconvoluted peaks, using typical Gaussion-Lorentz fitting, are shown in Fig. 2. The high-resolution Fe spectrum (Fig. 2A) reveals five peaks, with binding energies (BEs) of 711, 713, 719, 725, and 727 eV. The peaks located at BEs of 711 and 725 eV are assigned to 2p3/2 and 2p1/2 of the Fe2þ signal, while peaks at 713 and 727 eV correspond to 2p3/2 and 2p1/2 of Fe3þ, respectively. The one positioned at BE of 719 eV is a typical satellite peak for the other four peaks. [29] The presence of Fe3þ can be justified by partial oxidation of Fe2þ. The S spectrum
Scheme 1. Schematic diagram for the preparation of FeS/NDC (N-doped-C) composites.
J. Xie et al.
Journal of Power Sources 431 (2019) 226–231
(Fig. 2B) shows four peaks at BEs of 161, 164, 168, and 170 eV. The former two peaks belong to 2p of S, whereas the latter two can be ascribed to S-O groups due to the oxidation of S2- in air. [19] The high-resolution XPS spectrum of C element in Fig. 2C highlights three peaks located at BEs of 284, 286 and 288 eV, assigned to sp2 C, the combination of C-N bonding and sp3 C, and the bond of N-C¼O, respectively. [30] The presence of C-N bond signal in FeS/NDC confirms the existence of NDC, consistent with previously presented XRD and EDX results. The N spectrum (Fig. 2D) shows four peaks at BEs of 398, 400, 401, and 404 eV, respectively corresponding to pyridinic-N, pyrrolic-N, graphitic-N, and pyridinic-N-O groups. [20] Such results verify the existence of N, which is bonded to carbon to construct NDC-frameworks. N-doping not only enhances overall electronic conductivity, but also helps to anchor some key species effectively, thus boosting lithium storage performances, as will be discussed in the following.
Benefiting from unique NDC coating microstructures, FeS/NDC electrodes exhibit high electrochemical lithium storage performances (Fig. 3). Fig. 3A shows the first three galvonostatic discharge/charge (1C, 1C ¼ 609 mA g 1, 1-3 V) curves of the FeS/NDC cathode, showing well-defined and symmetric discharge/charge plateaus. The plateaus at ~1.5 V (during discharging after 1st cycle) and 1.8 V (during charging) correspond to the conversion processes of FeS, i.e., FeSþ2Liþþ2e ↔Li2S þ Fe. The first charge capacity is 726 mAh g 1, with an initial Coulombic efficiency (CE) of 80%. The charge capacity is ~621 mAh g 1 at 1C after 200 cycles, with the retention of 85.6% (Fig. 3B). The CE for subsequent cycling grows up to nearly 100% after initial three active processes (Fig. 3C). These ultra-stable cycling performances can be further confirmed by the almost overlapped CV profiles, showing high repetitions after 1st cycle (Fig. S3). The major current peaks at ~1.42 V and 1.84 V belong to the conversion processes of FeS, i.e., FeSþ2Liþþ2e ↔Fe þ Li2S, in consistent with the welldefined, very flat and symmetric discharge/charge plateaus observed in the galvonostatic discharge/charge curves. [13] The rate performance is displayed in Fig. 3D. As the specific current stepwise increases from 1C to 2C, 4C, 8C, and 10C, the average capacity is 675, 656, 638, 615, and 600 mAh g 1, respectively (Fig. 3D). When the current turns back to 1C
after heavy-duty cycles, a capacity of 660 mAh g 1 is recovered, suggesting extremely promising cycling sustainability. The additional capacity higher than theoretical value of 609 mAh g 1 is similar to previous reports, and could be ascribed to electrolyte decomposition on carbon supports, as the working voltage of FeS is below the level of the highest occupied molecular orbital (HOMO) of the electrolytes. [20,21, 31] Taking into account the pronounced high-rate performances, long-term cycling test at 10C is further carried out. A charge capacity keeps ~402 mAh g 1 at 10C even after 400 cycles with high CEs (Fig. 3E). The lithium storage capacity of FeS/NDC is higher than that of commercial LiCoO2 cathodes (~140 mAh g 1). Thereof, in spite of lower working voltages, FeS/NDC can still deliver a relatively higher energy density than LiCoO2 cathodes (~550 Wh kg 1), rendering it as competitive cathodes for Li storage. The remarkable electrochemical performances should be ascribed to the unique NDC coating structures, as aforementioned, which protect FeS from electrolyte corrosions and provide rapid Liþ/e transfer kinetics since the charge transfer resistance (Rct, Fig. S4) of the FeS/NDC composites (213 Ohm) is much lower than that of FeS (392 Ohm).
To further gain molecular-level insight into the role of N-doping in the electrochemical operation of FeS/NDC cathodes, we compute with DFT the adsorption energies (EadsÞ of FeS, Fe, and Li2S on a range of possible NDC sites (Table 1). From XPS results shown in Fig. 2D, we consider adsorption on graphitic-N, pyridinic-N, and pyrrolic-N sites as well as graphene-like sites for comparisons. Corresponding materials models are shown in Figs. S5–7. Results summarized in Table 1 indicate that the adsorption of FeS, Fe, and Li2S is indeed much stronger on Ndoped systems than on plain graphene-like sites, especially for the cases of pyridinic-N and pyrrolic-N sites. Hence, compared with plain carbon, NDC can anchor FeS, Fe, and Li2S species more effectively.

sections.heading: 4. Conclusions
sections.text:
In summary, we directly synthesize 3D micro/nano-structure FeS/ NDC composites by a novel method of facile precipitation and calcination. Such composites present unique 3D flower-like shapes assembled
J. Xie et al.
Journal of Power Sources 431 (2019) 226–231
with 2D nanosheets, and the individual FeS is coated by highly conductive NDC. The FeS/NDC composites can be employed as both anodes and cathodes depending on the voltage regime. Herein, we opt to examine their usability as cathodes for the first time, since the relatively low voltage can be compensated by low polarization and high capacity. We find that the unique NDC coating structures of FeS/NDC cathodes yield excellent cycling stability and high rate capability. In addition, molecular-level insight using DFT calculations reveals that the NDC adsorption sites are indeed able to anchor FeS, Fe, and Li2S more effectively than plain carbon, which provides further evidence for the outstanding Li storage performances. Overall, this work discloses a novel and essential route to exploit transition metal sulfides for Li storage, and helps us deep understand the crucial role of N-doping in electrochemical energy storage.

sections.heading: Appendix A. Supplementary data
sections.text: Supplementary data to this article (Table for EDS results; TGA-DTG curves, wide-range survey XPS spectra, CV and EIS curves of the FeS/ NDC; DFT computed total energies, structures, and optimized coordinates.) can be found online at https://doi.org/10.1016/j. jpowsour.2019.05.041.

metadata.abstractText: � A creative synthesis method of FeS/Ndoped-C composites is proposed. � FeS/N-doped-C composites own unique 3D flower-like micro/nano-structures. � FeS/N-doped-C composites are evaluated as cathodes for the first time. � FeS/N-doped-C electrodes exhibit extraordinary cycling stability and rate
